outputs.output_descr: The Peace and Development Programme (PDP) will strengthen national processes/ policies and institutions that can improve the ability of the society to prevent and manage conflicts. In particular PDP will work with national Government institutions, Advisory Committees (peace councils), civil society and other local mechanisms for peace to strengthen conflict analysis and response capacities at district, provincial and national level, enabling to effectively and systematically prevent/ manage conflicts. Besides building national capacities in monitoring and responding to tensions, PDP will provide technical support and training to relevant State institutions, selected LSGs, and citizens in selected LGSs to ensure the implementation of policies and local peacebuilding initiatives that reduce local inequalities, divisions and conflict, which will result in increased trust between different communities, and between communities and central and local authorities.
Surge Support Project for the Consultation and Prioritization of PBF peacebuilding priorities in Kyrgyzstan

The project will promote equal opportunities for youth to positively engage in society, also giving them opportunities to voice their grievances (e.g. through the media component and the implementation of youth action plans). Youth will acquire practical skills during the delivery of the youth work curriculum, implementation of youth action plans and livelihoods mentoring. This in turn will help changing youth and their communities, making sure that youth problems are voiced and better addressed. Vulnerable young women and young men at-risk will have better civic participation skills to positively engage in society. Additionally relevant institutions will have the capacity to replicate the delivery of the youth work curricula elsewhere. Policy makers at different levels will get an understanding of the youth issues that lead to their exclusion, alienation and involvement in violence.

The project capacitates state institutions, selected LSGs, and citizens in selected LGSs to ensure the implementation of policies and local peacebuilding initiatives that reduce local inequalities, divisions and conflict, which will result in increased trust between different communities, and between communities and central and local authorities.

The project will promote equal opportunities for youth to positively engage in society, also giving them opportunities to voice their grievances (e.g. through the media component and the implementation of youth action plans). Youth will acquire practical skills during the delivery of the youth work curriculum, implementation of youth action plans and livelihoods mentoring. This in turn will help changing youth and their communities, making sure that youth problems are voiced and better addressed. Vulnerable young women and young men at-risk will have better civic participation skills to positively engage in society. Additionally relevant institutions will have the capacity to replicate the delivery of the youth work curricula elsewhere. Policy makers at different levels will get an understanding of the youth issues that lead to their exclusion, alienation and involvement in violence.

This outcome draws on a key strength of the previous Peace and Development Programme in that it will work with the Oblast Advisory Committees (OACs) that have been established as part of the 2007-2010 Peace and Development Analysis process. To address the gap identified in monitoring of and responding to conflict escalation, the Programme will build the capacity of the OACs to collaborate with other conflict prevention and management structures (including actors supported by other UN) in these processes. Over the medium to longer term, a simple but effective early warning and response system will be developed with civil society and Government counterparts that can address conflicts and link local-level peace councils with the national level decision makers.

PDP will continue its work on cross-border cooperation, involving communities, border guards/ custom officers and local authorities along the Kyrgyz-Tajik and Kyrgyz-Uzbek borders in particular. The support to border communities will include training, institution building, and mentoring of cross-border working groups to engage in joint problem solving and the implementation of community-based projects that help reducing tensions/ cross-border conflicts. A close collaboration with UNDP Tajikistan is envisaged to work with communities and authorities on the Tajik side of the border.  Building on best practices of UNDP's cross-border cooperation work, the programme will pilot collaborative approaches to conflict prevention and security that are based on a strong collaboration between communities, local authorities, border guards, and custom officers.

project_descr: The Peace and Development Programme (PDP) will strengthen national processes/ policies and institutions that can improve the ability of the society to prevent and manage conflicts.
